data.title: Added Mac documentation to config file
Fix for content pipeline models being drawn entirely black
data.body:
_Disclaimer: I know nothing about 3D graphics, XNA or MonoGame (aside from simple SpriteBatch stuff) so everything below could be wrong._

This push request is a quick fix to solve the black model problem with the content pipeline. Processing a model with MonoGame's pipeline and then drawing it using model.Draw() causes it to be drawn entirely black. However, if you process the model with XNA's pipeline and then load and Draw() the xnb in MonoGame it displays as expected. See these threads for more information on the problem:

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/4069
http://community.monogame.net/t/3d-models-appear-black/2596
http://community.monogame.net/t/problem-with-3d-objects-textures/2474
http://community.monogame.net/t/diagnosing-rendering-issues-for-3d-model-in-new-content-pipeline/1432

The problem occurs here:

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline/OpenAssetImporter.cs#L320

The pipeline checks if Assimp has imported a particular lighting property from the model's material, and if so, sets the relevant nullable property in a BasicMaterialContent object. If the particular lighting property is not found then the relevant BasicMaterialContent property remains null. When the BasicMaterialContent is serialized it uses GetValueOrDefault() which sets all the unfound lighting properties to the default float value of 0. Thus the resulting xnb model has Alpha and SpecularPower set to 0 causing it to be drawn entirely black:

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline/Serialization/Compiler/BasicEffectWriter.cs

Assimp .NET seems to provide sensible defaults when getting a lighting property for which no corresponding property was found in the model's material:

https://github.com/assimp/assimp-net/blob/master/AssimpNet/Material.cs#L253

So this patch changes the pipeline to always accept the value provided by Assimp .NET, which will be either the property from the model or the default value provided. This solves the black rendering problem on the handful of models I have tried (on Windows 10) but I don't know if it is a correct or appropriate fix.

As a final note here are the final lighting values from importing a simple untextured model in various ways (unlisted properties do not differ between the three methods).
## XNA Pipeline

Alpha = 1
DiffuseColor = 1 1 1
SpecularColor = 1 1 1
SpecularPower = 16
## Current MonoGame Pipeline

Alpha = 0
DiffuseColor = 0.8 0.8 0.8
SpecularColor = 0 0 0
SpecularPower = 0
## Patched MonoGame Pipeline

Alpha = 1
DiffuseColor = 0.8 0.8 0.8
SpecularColor = 0 0 0
SpecularPower = 1

data.title: [WindowsGL] back buffer is not resized when returning to window mode
[pipeline] El Capitan did some weird stuff with the $PATH and /usr/bin
data.body:
Because of these changes mono can no longer be created in /usr/bin
as its read only. So the mono project have moved that exe to
/usr/local/bin.. which makes sense..

But /usr/local/bin is ONLY included in the path for the terminal/shell
and NOT for Applicaitons. So we end up in a situation where calls
to mono don't work. So the fix is to search for the locations in
the Pipeline tool AND the Build .targets.

data.title: Texture2D.GetData<T>(T[], int, int) incorrect behaviour
data.body: When specifying a start index and element count in Texture2D.GetData, it's checking to see if the data array passed to it is of a length equal to startIndex + elementCount instead of comparing it to just elementCount.  This, of course, means that to get only the last pixel, you would need to pass an array equal to the size of the texture, instead of one with a length of 1.

data.title: Added Input methods for Web platform
data.body:
This PR implements the following stuff onto the Web platform:
- Mouse
- Keyboard
- Joystick
- Gamepad
- Some very basic window functionality

Notes:
- General:
  - <s>I renamed Web platform to Jsil platform because protobuild checks if the platform is "Web" and downloads the entire Jsil repo and then builds the source code, which is totally unneeded... we only need it's binaries. Plus one more dumb thing about this is that the repo it chooses is hardcoded inside Protobuild and it's: https://github.com/hach-que/JSIL
    - https://github.com/hach-que/Protobuild/blob/a31b25dbe1630db9b418726f3069e6622d93c603/Protobuild.Internal/Packages/PackageGlobalTool/KnownToolProvider.cs</s>
  - The way I implemented this is different then what was originally imagined, I combined C# with JS calls so all the JS stuff is still inside C#, the original idea was to create Stubs and write JS code separately  which would be weird for a C# repo
  - I tested all the code I wrote with Chrome and Firefox
- Mouse:
  - Javascript does not contain a function that allows us to set a mouse position, but it does contain a function that allows locking a mouse pointer, so in order to make setting cursor position possible I made the game capture the mouse and just track it's movement, and simulate that onto a fake mouse
- Game Window:
  - Unless the window size is specified, the game will use the size of the canvas it is drawn onto
  - The canvas that the game will use for drawing is the one with id "mgcanvas"
- Gamepad:
  - Triggers in Firefox go from -1 to 1, but Firefox default starting position is 0 (possible bug?), so for now the code is tracking trigger from 0 to 1
  - Triggers in Chrome are buttons
  - First time a new gamepad is connected and loaded will be a bit slower

Demo project: https://github.com/cra0zy/MGWeb

Next I will be working on audio stuff. Help from someone with WebGL would be nice, GraphicsDevice is a nightmare....

data.title: Windows DirectX: SupportedDisplayModes considers B8G8R8A8 and B5G6R5 formats
data.body:
Resolves #4220

In some cases `GraphicsAdapter.SupportedDisplayModes` would return no results because only BGR formats were available. This PR changes `SupportedDisplayModes` to also consider `B8G8R8A8_UNorm` and `B5G6R5_UNorm` formats, and more closely match XNA behaviour.

data.title: "DisplayMode.RefreshRate" can be incorrect (Windows DirectX)
data.body:
I've come across a couple of weird refresh rates such as 59.94006Hz and 59.96894Hz. In the Windows monitor settings, they appear as 59Hz (i.e. truncated). But in MonoGame, they're being rounded to 60Hz.

Normally I guess this wouldn't be much of an issue. But on one of my PCs I have both 59Hz and 60Hz modes, so in MonoGame they are both appearing as 60Hz and look like duplicates.

So the refresh rate needs to at least be truncated to match Windows. However, given that `DisplayMode.RefreshRate` seems to be a MonoGame only property (I couldn't find it in XNA), is there any reason why we can't just make it a float so that the precise refresh rate can be retrieved?

PS. I'm more than happy to submit a PR for this. But I just wanted to confirm how this should be resolved first.

data.title: "SupportedDisplayModes" returns no results (Windows DirectX)
data.body:
One of my testers recently tried my game on an older laptop they had. When they tried to set the video resolution though, there were none to select from. Looking into it, `GraphicsAdapter.DefaultAdapter.SupportedDisplayModes` was not returning anything at all.

After some investigation, I found the issue - the laptop only had BGR video modes (specifically `B5G6R5_UNorm`, `B8G8R8A8_UNorm`, and `B8G8R8A8_UNorm_SRgb`). But MonoGame is currently only looking for `R8G8B8A8_UNorm` modes.

Does anyone see any issue with enumerating through all the different `SharpDX.DXGI.Format` values and translating them to the relevant XNA `SurfaceFormat.Color`? (e.g. `Format.B5G6R5_UNorm` -> `SurfaceFormat.Bgr565`, `Format.B8G8R8A8_UNorm` -> `SurfaceFormat.Bgra32`, etc.)

I did notice that WindowGL is currently excluding everything but 32-bit colour modes. I'm not sure if there's a specific reason for this, but I thought it might be relevant and worth mentioning.

PS. I'm more than happy to submit a PR for this. But I just wanted to confirm how this should be resolved first.
